newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary improves deal with GE due to upturn - finmin.
newsitem.headline: Hungary improves deal with GE due to upturn - finmin.

text.p: Hungary was able to improve terms for selling a bank to GE General Electric Capital Corp because of the upturn in the country's economy, Finance Minister Peter Medgyessy told a news conference on Thursday.

"We were able to renegotiate the contract...partly due to the fact that uncertainties surrounding Hungary's economy have dissolved," Medgyessy said, referring to the sale of Budapest Bank (BB) to GE Capital and other investors.

Hungary sold a 27.4 percent stake in BB to GE Capital Services and gave it operational control over the bank in December 1995. The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) has a 32.4 percent stake and the Hungarian state 22.8 percent.
Medgyessy, speaking after a cabinet meeting, said Hungary's economic image was poor at the time of the sale and the contract contained unfavourable terms.
He renegotiated the contract in December, scrapping among others a state guarantee to buy back all BB shares if their value sank below 50 percent of the purchase price.
When putting the seal on the new contract on December 23, Hungary repurchased BB's loss-making Polgari Bank unit for 1.1 billion forints under an 8.25 billion forints buy-back guarantee.

BB's original privatisation was orchestrated by then finance minister Lajos Bokros, who resigned in February 1996 on the grounds that the prime minister did not support his social security reshuffle plans.
Medgyessy said the Finance Ministry's briefing on the sale presented to the government in January 1996 was "biased and incomplete".
Opposition parties have called for a special parliamentary committee to look into the privatisation and the renegotiation of the contract.
